item.title: Call Of Duty: Warzone Season 1 Rank Reset Explained
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/call-of-duty-warzone-season-1-rank-reset-explained/1100-6527765/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Call of Duty's Season 1 update is now live in Warzone, bringing Black Ops 6's full integration, including the new movement system, weapon pool, and additional features. The update also resets players' ranks, as Black Ops 6 introduces Call of Duty's classic Prestige system to Warzone.

For the first time ever, the classic Prestige system is introduced in Warzone. This also means that the update wipes the slate clean for everyone, resetting all player ranks for the new season. Here is everything you need to know about the reset for Season 1 of Warzone.

Call of Duty: Warzone - Official Area 99 Launch Trailer

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

How player levels works in Warzone Season 1

Season 1 features cross-progression between Black Ops 6 and Warzone, meaning your player level in Warzone will match whatever rank you are currently in Black Ops 6. So, if you're already Prestige 1 level 55 in Black Ops 6, that's the rank you'll see when you log in to Warzone.

You'll start fresh at level 1 if you haven't played Black Ops 6. Playing and earning XP will increase your rank from 1 to the max rank of level 55. After you've completed level 55, you'll have the option to Prestige, which re-locks your loadout items and sends you back to level 1. This is a rinse-and-repeat cycle that might sound tedious for some battle-royale players, but you can earn some sweet exclusive rewards.

More in-depth Prestige details and a look at the rewards can be found here, which includes operator skins, weapon blueprints, and nostalgic loading screens inspired by past Black Ops games.

How weapon levels work for Warzone in Season 1

Warzone is adding Black Ops 6 weapons to the already large weapon pool that includes guns from previous years. Even though your rank is reset, you'll still keep the levels of any guns you've used.

This means you can still pick your favorite gun from MW2 or MW3 and have all your attachments unlocked and ready to go, or you can choose one of the new Black Ops 6 weapons for your loadout.

Any weapon progression in Black Ops 6 multiplayer and Zombies will carry over to Warzone, but if you haven't played the game yet, you'll need to unlock those weapons at the required rank, and then level those weapons up to get attachments unlocked.

For the first time ever, Season 1 of Warzone also adds a unique Mastery camo grind for battle royale.

The Season 1 battle pass features over 100 items to unlock, which includes the new Krig C assault rifle and Saug submachine gun. You can find more highlights of the Season 1 content here.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Infinity Nikki, From Zelda: Breath Of The Wild Designer, Comes Out Next Month
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/infinity-nikki-from-zelda-breath-of-the-wild-designer-comes-out-next-month/1100-6527763/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Not even a month separates us from the launch of Infinity Nikki. The open-world fashion game is set to release December 5 on PC, PS5, iOS, and Android. Players will dress up in different ways to give Nikki new abilities on her adventure, which is being overseen by The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild game designer Kentaro Tominaga.

Infinity Nikki will be the console debut for the titular character, who's the stylish heroine from the Love Nikki: Dress Up Queen mobile game. She will be joined by her cute buddy Momo in the upcoming open-world game. In fact, the release date trailer--seen below--appears to show Momo as a playable character in Infinity Nikki at certain points.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Infinity Nikki - Official Release Date Announcement Trailer

There's definitely a chill vibe to the Infinity Nikki video, too. We see Nikki switching costumes on the fly, bike riding that segues into ET-like flying, and bug catching a la Animal Crossing. One of the different outfits for Nikki sees the heroine utilizing a magical flower to glide with the wind.

Tominaga previously spent about 20 years at Nintendo and served as a game designer on The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild as well as the director for that game's expansion pass. Tominaga also worked on Mario Kart Wii and The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword, among other titles.

Infinity Nikki is looking wildly popular ahead of release. In August, the open-world fashion game had already surpassed 12 million pre-registrations, and on X, the official Infinity Nikki account notes that all milestones have been met. That would mean the upcoming game has more than 30 million pre-registrations.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: New Xbox Campaign Reminds People Xbox Is More Than Just The Console
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/new-xbox-campaign-reminds-people-xbox-is-more-than-just-the-console/1100-6527759/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Ahead of the holiday season, and presumably to help drive sign-ups to Game Pass, Microsoft has rolled out a new ad campaign called "This Is An Xbox." The basic takeaway is that, as Microsoft has been saying for years, you don't have to buy an Xbox to play Xbox. That's because Xbox games are available across a variety of devices these days as part of Microsoft's new strategy to gain marketshare. Microsoft is, of course, is in third place against PlayStation and Nintendo.

Microsoft is going big for this ad campaign, with visuals set to appear in places like San Francisco, Atlanta, Chicago, Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, London, New York, and Berlin. Microsoft also commissioned a live-action trailer featuring the song "The Choice Is Yours" by Black Sheep, which is rather fitting.

Additionally, Microsoft partnered with companies like Samsung, Crocs, Porsche, and The Happy Egg for branding takeovers. The ads first display a product, say, a pair of Crocs, with the message "This is a pair of Crocs," and the next page shows an Xbox and says, "This is an Xbox."

Additionally, Microsoft is launching a giant billboard for "This Is An Xbox" at Times Square in New York City later this year. Beyond all that, Microsoft is selling themed merch at the Xbox Gear Shop, including a t-shirt that says "This Is Not An Xbox," referring to the human wearing the shirt.

There is also an online quiz that asks people to identify what is and what is not an Xbox. It's a pretty fun and silly quiz, and you can take it here.

This is a new ad campaign but the idea has been in place for years. In 2020, Microsoft Gaming CEO Phil Spencer said Xbox's goal is to increase the number of people playing on Xbox, but "playing on Xbox" doesn't mean a dedicated Xbox console. "It means somebody who is logging in and playing a part of our ecosystem, whether first-party or third-party. And it could be on an Android phone. It could be on a Switch. It could be on a PC. That's how we think about it," he said.

Game consoles usually do not make much money, and if they do, it's not a lot compared to the much more lucrative games and services. This is why Microsoft is pushing Xbox Game Pass so hard. Creating more subscribers gives Microsoft a regular and recurring revenue stream.

And Microsoft is all about making money. After Xbox's recent 2,500 layoffs, Spencer defended the cuts, saying they were necessary due to capitalism.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Xbox Handheld Device Is A "Few Years Out," Apparently
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/xbox-handheld-device-is-a-few-years-out-apparently/1100-6527758/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Microsoft Gaming CEO Phil Spencer has been saying for a long time that he wants to make an Xbox handheld device, and now he's brought it up once more.

Speaking to Bloomberg, Spencer said that the "expectation is that we would do something" in that area. Bloomberg reported that Microsoft is currently working on prototypes and thinking about the best way forward. The site also reported that Spencer said any potential Xbox handheld would be "a few years out."

For now, Microsoft's designers and engineers are spending time updating the Xbox mobile app to offer a better experience on portable gaming devices that already exist. But on a longer horizon, Spencer said, "I think our team could do some real innovative work" in the dedicated handheld market.

A report from September 2024 claimed that the next-generation Xbox console could also support a dedicated gaming handheld device. Microsoft is working on its next home console, saying the system will offer the "largest technical leap" in Xbox history.

Microsoft stands apart from PlayStation and Nintendo in that it's the only one of the so-called Big Three that has never released a dedicated portable gaming device--it seems it won't be that way forever, though.

Also in the interview, Spencer talked about Microsoft's mobile game store, noting that it's been delayed to an unspecified point in the future. It was previously expected to launch this past July.

Spencer also talked about the possibility of making more acquisitions, saying he's always considering options, but nothing is "imminent." Additionally, Spencer said Halo 5 on PS5 has not been ruled out.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
